unnormalised: ## Flash Sale Frenzy: Faster Than a Delhi Driver on Diwali!
normalised: ## Flash Sale Frenzy: Faster Than a Delhi Driver on Diwali!

unnormalised: Alright folks, put down your chai and listen up! We're diving headfirst into the chaotic, exhilarating, and occasionally terrifying world of Flash Sales! Think of it as a stampede at a Lajpat Nagar sale, but online and slightly less likely to result in someone shouting "Arre yaar!".
normalised: Alright folks, put down your chai and listen up! We're diving headfirst into the chaotic, exhilarating, and occasionally terrifying world of Flash Sales! Think of it as a stampede at a Lajpat Nagar sale, but online and slightly less likely to result in someone shouting "Arre yaar!".

unnormalised: These blink-and-you'll-miss-it sales are the digital equivalent of your phuppo grabbing the last gulab jamun at a wedding. Seriously, they're gone faster than you can say "Aadhaar card update". We've all been there, haven't we? Refreshing the page every 0.5 seconds, desperately trying to snag that trendy kurta from Myntra or that pressure cooker before your neighbour, Sharma aunty, does. The sheer adrenaline rush is enough to keep you going for days (and maybe develop a mild twitch).
normalised: These blink-and-you'll-miss-it sales are the digital equivalent of your phuppo grabbing the last gulab jamun at a wedding. Seriously, they're gone faster than you can say "Aadhaar card update". We've all been there, haven't we? Refreshing the page every zero point five seconds, desperately trying to snag that trendy kurta from Myntra or that pressure cooker before your neighbour, Sharma aunty, does. The sheer adrenaline rush is enough to keep you going for days (and maybe develop a mild twitch).

unnormalised: Retailers love 'em, because let's face it, they create a sense of urgency that would make even Dr. Gupta from Apollo Hospital proud. "Limited stock! Sale ends in 5 minutes!" The fear of missing out (FOMO, as the kids call it) is a powerful motivator. Suddenly, you need that inflatable flamingo for your balcony (even though you live in a 500 sq ft apartment in Chembur). You convince yourself it’s a *necessity*.
normalised: Retailers love 'em, because let's face it, they create a sense of urgency that would make even Doctor Gupta from Apollo Hospital proud. "Limited stock! Sale ends in five minutes!" The fear of missing out (F O M O, as the kids call it) is a powerful motivator. Suddenly, you need that inflatable flamingo for your balcony (even though you live in a five hundred square foot apartment in Chembur). You convince yourself it's a *necessity*.

unnormalised: And let’s not forget the discounts! Rs. 500 off! 70% off! It's enough to make you forget about your budget and start calculating how many sarees you can buy with the savings (even though your wardrobe already resembles a textile museum).
normalised: And let's not forget the discounts! Rupee five hundred off! seventy percent off! It's enough to make you forget about your budget and start calculating how many sarees you can buy with the savings (even though your wardrobe already resembles a textile museum).

unnormalised: But a word of caution, my friends. Don’t get so caught up in the frenzy that you end up buying something you absolutely don't need. Remember that 6-foot tall statue of Lord Ganesha you impulse-purchased last year? Yeah, exactly.
normalised: But a word of caution, my friends. Don't get so caught up in the frenzy that you end up buying something you absolutely don't need. Remember that six-foot tall statue of Lord Ganesha you impulse-purchased last year? Yeah, exactly.

unnormalised: So, embrace the chaos, strategize your clicks, and may the best (and fastest) shopper win! But always remember to breathe, maybe do some yoga, and remember that life is more than just a perfectly timed online purchase. Unless, of course, it's a discounted Royal Enfield, then all bets are off. Happy shopping!
normalised: So, embrace the chaos, strategize your clicks, and may the best (and fastest) shopper win! But always remember to breathe, maybe do some yoga, and remember that life is more than just a perfectly timed online purchase. Unless, of course, it's a discounted Royal Enfield, then all bets are off. Happy shopping!
